data.description:
Introduction

Back in February, my thesis on Canadian National Railway (CNI) was a classic buy-the-dip scenario. The stock was beaten down with significant tariff uncertainty, with fears over the impact on the firm’s earnings. Since then, the dip has only deepened.

Despite the deepening of the dip, I still have a positive view of Canadian National’s shares. Recently released Q3 numbers, while weaker than the 10-15% EPS growth initially guided for 2025, still show growing EPS nonetheless. This is despite the uncertain trading landscape Canadian National has faced.

The fact is Canadian National still remains a major North American railroad, with a vast route network that cannot be replicated, limiting competition. Against trucking, the only other major way to move vast quantities of goods over land, the economics are strongly in rail's favor.

All this has led to above-market returns over the long run. Average returns on equity stand at 27%, and operating margins that average 40%, enable Canadian National to provide considerable returns to shareholders. The company boasts 29 years of continuous dividend growth since its IPO in 1995, rising at an average cumulative annual growth rate of 15%. Throw in the share buybacks, and it improves even further.

Now, Canadian National is going through a tough period, with tariffs impacting trade flows in ways the company has never experienced before. This has put pressure on the share price this year.

I remain positive, however. The latest Q3 results are nowhere near the disaster many thought tariffs would bring, and the valuation compared to recent years looks attractive. Let’s explore Canadian National further.

Q3 Results

Canadian National recently reported its earnings for Q3 ’25, giving a clear view of the current impact of tariffs. Revenues came in at C$4.17 billion, an increase of 1% from the previous year, and beat consensus estimates by C$20 million.

There were no large changes in any one segment with the exception of intermodal, which saw revenues rise 11%, driven by a 15% increase in carloads. This segment was a major cause of concern earlier this year with the risk of port disruptions and fears over trade flows, but this strong growth is the clearest sign yet that the tariff fears were vastly overblown.

Revenue only tells one part of the story, however. Earnings are, for most investors, the more important number. Here, Canadian National delivered an earnings beat, with a 6% increase in operating income to C$1.61 billion and a 6% rise in adjusted EPS to C$1.83.

With revenue growth only at 1%, a 6% rise in earnings was driven by Canadian National’s margin expansion due to strong cost control. Total operating expenses fell 1% from the previous year, despite the wider inflationary environment.

A 20% fall in fuel expenses due to the removal of the Canadian federal carbon tax, lower fuel prices, and a 2% gain in fuel efficiency led to a C$101 million saving. In addition, labor costs were kept in check, falling 2%, driven by workforce reductions.

This combination of intermodal holding up despite the tariff risks supporting a small growth in revenue, and falling operating expenses led to a 1.7% improvement in the operating ratio from the previous year, which fell to 61.4%. While the fall in fuel costs may largely be due to factors outside management's control, the increase in labor productivity, which led to a reduction in labor costs, shows management is actively focused on making the firm more profitable.

During the quarter, Canadian National posted cash flows from operations of C$1.9 billion, up from C$1.8 billion a year earlier, which, after accounting for C$1.12 billion in investing activities, gave a free cash flow of C$793 million, a C$209 million increase from a year earlier. Also announced in earnings was that 2026 capital expenditures are now expected to be C$550 million lower, which should result in improved cash flow in the coming year.

With the year heading to a close, management affirmed that the firm remains on track to meet its guidance for mid- to high single digit earnings per share growth. This is set to be driven by continued strong performance across the intermodal and bulk volumes to finish the year.

Overall, Canadian National posted a modestly positive set of results, which showed improved efficiency causing a decrease in the operating ratio, which was countered by revenue growth of only 1%, which stopped these from being strong results. With three-quarters of the year now reported, Canadian National is on track to reach its full-year EPS growth forecast, though continued volume growth will be key for this to continue into 2026.

Valuation

Railroads are a cyclical industry, exposed to the wider economic environment, and the trade flows of a country. As such, I believe it is best to take a longer-term view when considering an investment in Canadian National. Over the past couple of years, existing shareholders may have underperformed the S&P500 index, but when this is expanded to a multi-decade view, it shows above market returns.

When we compare Canadian National to its North American railroad peers: Canadian Pacific Kansas City (CP), CSX (CSX), Union Pacific (UNP), Norfolk Southern (NSC), we see that for many of them, they're trading at their lowest price-to-earnings multiple in five years. And this isn’t an artificially low multiple because we are at the peak of a cycle; this is one of the toughest years in a while for railroads, given the impact of trade uncertainty. Of course, things could still get tougher next year, but this isn’t a buying-at-the-peak scenario, and I am firmly of the view that in the long run, freight volumes will continue to grow, supporting railroads with their strong economics.

Currently, Canadian National trades at the lowest valuation amongst its peer group, and while its exposure to cross-border trade may be higher, the discount seems excessive, especially when Canadian Pacific Kansas City Southern faces a similar impact.

This comes despite Canadian National having some of the best characteristics of the railroads:

  • 3 coast reach, enabling an unmatched network across the Atlantic, Pacific, and Gulf coasts, reducing reliance on any single trade corridor.
  • Superior fuel economy, with one of the lowest fuel consumptions per gross ton mile supporting lower costs.
  • Access to Prince Rupert, North America’s closest port to Asia, providing faster transit times and long-term capacity growth prospects, while allowing the avoidance of congestion at other West Coast ports.
  • Operational flexibility around the congested Chicago gateway, giving Canadian National the ability to interchange and move traffic effectively.

In the long run, Canadian National continues to look strongly positioned with the ability to continue generating stable free cash flow, even during weakness in the freight market.

To complement this relative valuation, let’s put a price target on Canadian National. In 2025, revenue is on track to be $12.35 billion, and assuming 4% growth in 2026 due to volume and pricing growth, we get revenue of $12.84 billion. To determine EBIT, I calculated Canadian National’s EBIT margin over the past 5 years and estimate it to remain stable at 42.5%.

To determine an exit EV/EBIT multiple, I took the midpoint of the company’s 5-year average of 18.22 and the industry average of 17.49 to get an exit multiple of 17.85. I then reduce this by 1 to account for the fact that Canadian National may be hit harder than other railroads by the impact of tariffs, given its large cross border business.

This method balances the company’s historical valuation multiple with that of similar companies and considers CNI’s valuation to peers, trends in the industry, and CNI’s historical performance.

If we assume that cash and debt levels remain constant with any cash flow reinvested, paid out in dividends, or used for share buybacks, running the calculations implies a market cap of $76.7 billion for the end of 2026.

If we assume that Canadian National buys back 3% of its shares outstanding over the course of the next year, we reach 599 million shares outstanding at the end of 2026. This translates to a share price target of USD$128.05, suggesting Canadian National remains attractively valued.

In terms of major risks, while the biggest risk of tariffs appears to have faded, this could always change. Canada only currently faces an effective tariff of 3% on exports to the U.S., given all the carve-outs and exemptions, but this could always change, impacting cross-border freight volumes. There is also the risk that weaker, wider economic conditions hit volumes.

Finally, CNI is exposed to potential operational disruptions. As we have seen in previous quarters, natural events such as the freezing weather disrupted shipments, and in the past wildfires and flooding have reduced freight volumes and earnings. Labor disputes both at CNI and external companies like port operators remain another key risk CNI faces, leading to operational disruption. Although strike action is incredibly disruptive, union activity can also result in significant pay increases, leading to higher labor costs.

Conclusion

Canadian National’s Q3 results presented a solid beat. Revenues experienced a small rise with strong cost control leading to expenses falling, resulting in EPS growth of 6%. This came despite one of the most challenging operating environments in recent years.

While tariff uncertainty and weaker freight demand continue to weigh on the share price, I don’t believe these will be a long-term drag on the company. Canadian National remains one of the strongest railroads with an unmatched three-coast network and access to Prince Rupert that position it for long-term growth.

At current levels, the valuation looks undemanding, trading below peers and at the lowest multiple in five years. With a nearly three decade record of dividends and share buybacks, my 2026 price target of $128 implies strong upside from current prices.

With strong long-term fundamentals, I continue to believe Canadian National is a high-quality position to hold in a portfolio for the long term. I continue to assign a buy rating.

data.title: I Just Made A Big Bet - And Reshaped My Dividend Portfolio Around It
data.description:
Introduction

Usually, I do not write many articles covering my entire portfolio, or at least not on a very frequent basis. That’s due to a number of reasons, including the fact that I'm somewhat unorthodox when it comes to investing. Unlike many, I do not put cash to work on a regular basis. While I often reinvest dividends, I often build larger cash positions to invest in my highest-conviction ideas instead of buying for a fixed amount every month.

Another reason is that I own just 16 individual stocks with a very low turnover rate, as I rarely make major changes to my portfolio. I also do not collect a lot of data. Unlike many who have a fancy chart for every portfolio statistic, I just keep it simple and put as much money as possible (within reason) into my highest-conviction ideas with a very long time horizon.

The market will do the rest.

With that said, I have written quite a few articles recently, including an article titled "My Entire Financial Future Relies On These 16 Stocks" on Oct.14. Then, on Oct. 28, I wrote "My Portfolio’s Biggest Problem - And The 4 Stocks I’m Betting On Next."

I have to say that the Oct. 28 article was somewhat unexpected as it was about how concentrated my portfolio had become. I explained how the >180% surge in the Comfort Systems USA (FIX) stock price had boosted that position to more than 17.0% of my portfolio. This resulted in the top three investments accounting for 43% of my entire liquid net worth.

Hence, I spent a lot of time discussing why I hate selling, in general, how professionals assess this topic, what kind of questions I think we all should be asking before selling, and what I expect to do with the proceeds. Please feel free to read it if you haven’t already. I was really happy with the replies and super glad I could add value to people’s own investment process.

Going back to FIX, the main reason I decided to actually sell is because of its valuation. I was up more than 180% on an investment bought in March. It now trades at more than 40x earnings in a market where everyone and their pet knows that AI is a hot trend. While I still love FIX and believe it will trade much higher ten years from now, I started to dislike the risk/reward, especially in light of other terrific opportunities.

So, I pulled the trigger. I sold FIX, freeing up more than 17% cash. And, as I promised, I deployed this capital, as I have never been a net seller since I started long-term investing.

In this article, I’ll give you a quick overview of my new portfolio structure, discuss three of my smaller investments, and then spend way more time on the one big addition to my portfolio that I have been eyeing for a while.

As I am super excited to share this with you, let’s get right to it.

My 3 Additions and My Four Big Portfolio Themes

I’m going to keep this part rather short for two reasons:

  • The companies I added to are often featured in my articles.
  • My new portfolio addition will require a lot of attention, which means I need to keep my word count in this part subdued.

The funny thing is that the transactions I made barely impacted my total portfolio worth. After all, I simply rotated some cash. If we ignore a few grand in dividends that I also reinvested, my total portfolio value remained unchanged.

However, it doesn’t feel like that, as I exchanged a huge position in a company for what I consider a rich valuation for four investments with terrific valuations. To me, it feels like I now have a much stronger portfolio.

As I already hinted in my prior article, I doubled my positions in Old Dominion Freight Line (ODFL) and Carlisle Companies (CSL), two companies that embody two of my biggest theses, which are transportation (cyclical value) and housing/construction remodeling.

Because both companies performed rather poorly (to put it mildly) this year, I'm very happy I used this opportunity to substantially boost my stake in these companies, making them my fourth and sixth-largest investments.

I also boosted my investment in LandBridge (LB) yet again. I know it somewhat defeats my argument that I want to avoid being too top-heavy, as LB now accounts for 16.4% of my portfolio, but I simply love this investment and the combo of energy, water, and commercial infrastructure in the Permian Basin.

After making these changes and buying the new investment I’m about to show you in just a second, I now have a portfolio that is dominated by four major industries:

  • My two landowners, Texas Pacific Land (TPL) and LandBridge, account for 27% of my portfolio. Officially, landowners aren’t an industry, but I decided to go with a customer classification here. This perfectly embodies my bullishness on energy, Permian water, and surface operations like AI-related infrastructure.
  • Roughly a fifth of my portfolio consists of defense companies. Here, I didn’t change anything. These are mostly anti-cyclical defense and commercial giants like RTX Corp. (RTX), GE Aerospace (GE), Northrop Grumman (NOC), and L3Harris Technologies (LHX).
  • Freight & logistics cover my two Class I railroads, Union Pacific (UNP) and Canadian Pacific Kansas City (CP). Both investments have done poorly for more than four years and are critical to my cyclical value thesis. It also includes my just-boosted investment in ODFL.
  • The biggest change is the fact that I now have 15% exposure to the homebuilding industry. This is because of my larger investment in CSL and because of my latest investment. Homebuilding is one of my biggest theses as I believe the market is massively undersupplied and benefiting from decades of underinvestment in maintenance. My most recent article on this subject got more than 230 comments.

Now, let’s dive into my new investment!

Why I Just Went Big Into QXO, Inc. (QXO)

QXO is a company I have increasingly brought up in recent articles. Especially the ones where I focused on just how bullish I am on housing on a longer-term basis (i.e., the article I just mentioned).

Interestingly, QXO does not pay a dividend, which makes it somewhat of a unique case in my portfolio. I also do not expect it to pay a dividend for many years, as this is an M&A-focused business with a very clear vision that I will get to in a bit.

Besides that QXO perfectly fits my thesis as I will explain in this article, I also feel rather close with the company, as I have been in frequent contact with someone from their executive team and even had various exchanges with their Chairman, Founder, and Chief Executive Officer Brad Jacobs, the billionaire investor who has one of the best track records of value generation in all of America.

However, and this is very important for you to know:

  • I have never received any information that wasn’t public.
  • I have never been asked to cover QXO or say anything positive about the company.
  • Besides a free PDF copy of Brad Jacob’s book, I have never received anything of value, whether it’s a tangible good or money. Nothing. Nada.
  • None of this will change.

Now that I have gotten that out of the way, I can tell you what QXO is all about.

See, even before QXO was founded, Brad Jacobs and I (independently from each other, of course) had the same view, which is that there’s tremendous money in America’s housing and commercial construction market.

I turned this into a tangible idea by buying Carlisle Companies and explaining to investors that the average commercial building is more than 50-years-old, while the residential market has been substantially undersupplied. Brad Jacobs turned his vision into reality by investing a billion dollars' worth of equity into a company called SilverSun Technologies in June of last year.

The short version of this complex transaction is that Mr. Jacobs got a public company without having to build something from the ground up and IPO it. After investing in SilverSun, they changed the name to QXO and had a legal vehicle they could use for M&A.

That also explains why the QXO stock price looks like this:

With that said, the name QXO is similar to other companies that Brad Jacobs has founded, as the multi-billionaire investor has also founded, among others, United Rentals (URI) and XPO (XPO), which spun off GXO (GXO) and RXO (RXO). All of these companies are leaders in their fields due to successful AI, technology implementation, and organic growth/higher efficiencies.

I'm not saying to curry favor, but XPO and URI (ignoring spin-offs) have truly become American success stories with massive shareholder returns, as the chart below shows.

If I had to summarize his game plan, it would be something like this:

  • Identify a high-demand market. United Rentals benefited from the demand for asset-light machinery operations. XPO serviced a rapidly growing less-than-truckload market.
  • Use free cash flow and external funding to acquire businesses in highly fragmented markets. Both trucking and the rental business were and still are fragmented.
  • Incorporate new businesses and improve them through technology.
  • Use accelerating cash flows to keep the balance sheet healthy and build even more room for M&A.

Essentially, Mr. Jacobs has been playing Monopoly in hot markets for many decades.

The major difference now is that he did not IPO his own business but bought SilverSun. He then went on to buy Beacon Roofing Supply, a company that initially resisted a takeover. The deal was completed in April of this year for roughly $11 billion and turned QXO into a leader of the roofing supply market.

As you can imagine, Jacobs and his team moved quickly and did not waste any time building a strong foundation for growth in what they consider to be an $800 billion market opportunity:

“Acquiring Beacon is a major step forward in our strategy to make QXO the leading tech-enabled company in the $800 billion building products distribution industry,” said Brad Jacobs, chairman and chief executive officer of QXO. “We’re excited to welcome Beacon’s talented team and, together, apply our proven playbook to accelerate growth, expand margins, and create an unmatched customer experience.” - QXO News Release

QXO, which has President Trump’s son-in-law, Jared Kushner, as an independent director on its board, made a smart move by starting in the roofing business. In addition to giving the company actual cash flows and a tangible business, it’s also 80% driven by non-discretionary repair and remodeling operations. That’s what I love so much about this distribution business, as the company benefits from both new construction and remodeling needs without having to produce its own products. As a result, Beacon generated positive organic revenue growth in 17 out of 21 years since going public in 2004.

The deal also gave the company roughly 600 branches with 110,000 customers and 135,000 unique products. This includes sidings, roofing tiles, weatherproofing, and everything you can think of from a massive supplier base that includes Carlisle Companies.

Now, this footprint is being used to generate the foundation for an aggressive takeover of a market with roughly 7,000 distributors in North America alone, a shortage of 4 million homes (see below), a substantially aging housing stock, and at least $2 trillion in required infrastructure spending.

The best thing is that QXO is also an AI play as it uses technology to streamline operations, integrate new businesses, and better predict demand and supply, among other things. Think about it - if AI is great for something, I think it’s for a business that deals with millions of orders, hundreds of thousands of customers and sellers, and volatile demand impacting inventory demand. Here's a great link from IBM that shows these benefits.

On its board, it has a number of heavyweights with terrific track records:

  • Jeff England as Chief Supply Chain Officer: He has a background as Senior VP Supply Chain at Walmart (WMT), one of the most efficient consumer goods companies on the planet, if you ask me.
  • Val Liborski is Chief Technology Officer with a background at Amazon Web Services and Microsoft (MSFT), two of the biggest hyperscalers on the market.
  • It has a Chief Artificial Intelligence Officer named Ashwin Rao with a background in investment banking and advanced degrees from places like the University of Southern California and Stanford University.

Moreover, two-thirds of the CEO and CFO equity compensation is tied to total shareholder returns, something Brad Jacobs cares deeply about.

When it bought Beacon, it started the transformation on day one, as I already mentioned. This includes a new e-commerce website and mobile app, better customer communications, a streamlined organizational chart, better cost inflation flows, and a renewed focus on sales growth.

In general, I think they made a wise choice, as I spent a lot of time visiting its centers on Google Maps. Most had terrific reviews from both customers and logistics providers.

When it comes to guidance, the company expects to double EBITDA at legacy Beacon purely organically (without M&A) within five years.

This brings me to its valuation.

Putting a valuation on a company like QXO is tough. While we can work with organic growth, it’s a company that will use any opportunity it has to buy new players and rapidly expand its footprint. Especially during times of weakness among cyclical housing stocks, I can imagine the M&A team at QXO is working overtime.

For starters, Wall Street is bullish. Using the Seeking Alpha overview below, we see the company has 12 Strong Buy ratings. That’s out of 15. The average price target is nearly 80% above its current price. Needless to say, that’s a lot of optimism, one could say.

One of the most bullish companies on the street is Wolfe Research, which has a price target of $44 on the company, roughly 140% above the current price. I looked into its findings (paywalled research) and believe they have done a great job assessing the risk/reward.

For example, the company agrees with QXO, as it sees doubling organic EBITDA and total EBITDA of more than $4.5 billion by 2030. It believes the company can achieve this without raising more equity, using free cash flow, and higher margins, while also doubling the EBITDA of newly bought businesses.

Essentially, QXO is expected to grow organic EBITDA by 15% per year. This is possible based on volumes and higher margins. After all, as I already mentioned, the distribution business is the perfect breeding ground for higher margins, especially when effectively using AI tools.

Moreover, it uses a 17x multiple for its 2030 EBITDA estimates and discounts it using its cost of capital. Despite having such a bullish rating, Wolfe does not believe it’s too aggressive as 17x EBITDA would be in line with the S&P 500 industrials sector. In fact, given that QXO has the capacity to far outpace the growth of its peers, it could deserve a higher multiple. At 17x earnings, it would be competing with other efficient distribution businesses, including Watsco (WSO) and Pool Corp. (POOL), which are both companies I admire for their operations.

Additionally, the company expects QXO to maintain a 3x leverage ratio, which should provide it with the stability needed to take on debt at attractive rates if it has to. S&P Global has given the company a BB- rating. Although this is not an investment-grade rating, it's very normal for a conservative rating at this stage of its growth expansion.

This is what S&P Global wrote with regard to QXO's future, which shows how promising its growth and debt reduction plans are:

The stable outlook on QXO Inc. indicates our expectation of S&P Global Ratings-adjusted leverage of just over 5x and operating cash flow (OCF) to debt in the low end of the 15%-25% range in 2025 with leverage improving comfortably within the 4x-5x range within 12 months. We expect the company will maintain margin performance which, in turn, will generate sufficient cash to reduce its debt balance. - S&P Global

In other words, despite its somewhat low rating, I see no reason to worry.

Morgan Stanley seems to agree with Wolfe, as I looked into their findings as well. The company called the company "A $50 Billion Pound Gorilla" and gave it an overweight rating with a $35 price target. Here’s what the research company, which I highly respect, wrote:

Too cheap for the CAGR: High quality US Distributors trade at premium multiples (~18x EBITDA) and QXO will compound EBITDA + cash flow at a significantly faster rate than the group, a supportive backdrop for QXO’s long-term re-rating prospects. QXO is expected to compound EBITDA at a ~40% CAGR through decade - roughly 5x the peer group, yet shares trade at a discount. Even if we exclude incremental M&A, we see QXO generating a ~20% EBITDA CAGR through 2030 on BECN turnaround which alone supports a $26 p/sh equity value on our math. - Morgan Stanley (paywalled research)

With that said, I think the only thing that decides whether Wolfe or Morgan Stanley is right is the pace of economic growth. If my housing thesis is right, we could see a substantial increase in building activity. This could create unexpected tailwinds for QXO.

Needless to say, as QXO perfectly fits my requirements, I made it my third-largest investment, which means it’s the biggest starter position ever of mine.

  • I feel great about the management team.
  • It perfectly aligns with my long-term housing view.
  • Its business model makes a lot of sense in a fragmented industry.
  • It could be one of the best examples of an efficient AI utilizer over time.
  • I think it’s way too cheap despite increasing coverage from Wall Street.

I will discuss the risks in the risk part of this article (below the takeaway).

All things considered, I will give QXO a lot more attention. This doesn’t mean I will bombard you with it on a daily basis, but use it more often in quarterly reports and to cover my housing thesis over time.

Takeaway

My portfolio overhaul has been finished.

After selling my Comfort Systems position due to risk/reward reasons, I now believe I have optimized the odds of beating the market for my portfolio. I doubled my investments in Old Dominion Freight Line, Carlisle, expanded LandBridge, and added a new ultra-high conviction idea, QXO.

It’s now my third-largest investment and my biggest started position ever.

I feel great about it, as I now have further solidified my four biggest investment theses, accounting for roughly three-fourths of my portfolio:

  • Landowners/energy
  • Defense
  • Wide-moat transportation
  • Housing suppliers

Moreover, and I cannot stress this enough, my portfolio is not an event-driven investment vehicle, as all of my holdings are long-term compounders with the ability to generate value even during tough economic times.

While I may regret selling FIX, I am quite upbeat about the future, the way things are now, as I believe even a small uptick in cyclical growth could propel my portfolio to new highs.

On a side note, here is a full overview of my holdings and their weighting:

The average dividend yield is now 1.5%.

Risks and A Few More Notes

I know I increased risks tied to cyclical growth. While FIX is a cyclical company as well, ODFL, CSL, LB, and QXO are all cyclical companies to some extent.

While LB has substantial non-oil revenue and QXO benefits from remodeling demand, a steep recession would likely create substantial stock price declines, even if it’s just temporary.

I'm fully aware of these risks. I know I'm running an unorthodox dividend growth portfolio.

That said, I'm looking to diversify. When I add new capital to my portfolio, I will likely diversify into non-industrial/energy sectors.

For QXO specifically, risks involve finding suitable M&A targets. While it has a promising organic growth outlook, it competes with large companies like Home Depot for new deals. One great example is how Home Depot also went after GMS and won the deal.

Other risks are tied to the integration of new companies and general technology improvements. Or, to put it differently, the company’s ambitious plans could unfold much more slowly than expected.

data.title: Clarivate: Downgrade To Hold As The Recovery Momentum Is Not Showing Up
data.description:
Investment Action

I had a buy rating for Clarivate (CLVT) previously, as I believed that the business was turning around as I expected, and with the stock at just ~6x forward PE, I thought it was really cheap. However, I am now downgrading CLVT to hold. The business is not recovering as well as I expect it to. The segments that needed to recover (IP and LSH) continue to be weak. At ~4.8x forward PE, the stock still looks inexpensive, but in my view, it deserves the discount until management can prove that organic growth is sustainable.

Earnings Results Review

CLVT Q3 2025 results were disappointing. The headline revenue looks good, but the underlying business is actually not doing as well. It reported total revenue of $623.1 million, which is basically flat y/y but was ahead of consensus. The reason for this beat needs attention, because it wasn’t driven by the core business. The beat came largely from several large, one-time, low-margin e-book transactions within the Academia & Government [ANG] segment, which CLVT is in the process of winding down (the e-book subsegment). In other words, this one-off tailwind is unlikely to happen again. Also, the reason for the FY2025 revenue guide to be raised was because this exit is taking longer than expected.

On an organic basis, revenue fell 0.1% y/y, a sequential deceleration vs. the 0.5% growth in Q2 2025. Subscription revenue grew 1.2% y/y, but this was fully offset by a 3.2% decline in recurring IP renewals and a 2.8% decline in transactional revenue. By segment, ANG was the only segment that grew, with 2% y/y organic growth, but the IP business fell 2.7% y/y, and Life Sciences & Healthcare [LSH] fell 0.7% y/y. As you can imagine, this impacted margins. Adj. EBITDA fell to $252.4 million from $264.4 million, with margins down 200 bps to 40.5%. Hence, at the bottom line, adj. EPS came in only at $0.18.

The Bull Case

While the flat organic headline performance was disappointing, there are some positive signals that supported my previous bull case. This is also why I see Q3 as a mixed bag rather than an outright miss. The most important leading indicator, in my view, remains organic annual contract value [ACV], which accelerated again to 1.6% growth. This was 1.3% in Q2, which I noted as the first real sign of a turnaround. With another quarter of improvement, ACV is now up 70 bps since FY2024, and this suggests that the current 1.2% growth in Q3’s subscription revenue can continue to accelerate.

The quality of this ACV improvement is also another very bullish development. I believe the real reason for this improvement is really the pivot to a subscription-first model. We can see this in the numbers. Recurring organic revenue is now 88% of total organic revenue on a year-to-date basis, up 800 bps from 80% for FY2024. The underlying customer health is also getting better as renewal rates are now at 93%, up 100 bps y/y, which confirms that the subscription model is resonating. This is perhaps one of the clearest signs that the business model is stabilizing.

Even the IP segment, which has been a major drag, has started to stabilize. Yes, the Q3 organic decline was ugly, but on a year-to-date basis, recurring patent revenue is now flat versus the 3% decline in 2024. That is the type of improvement I want to see, as it suggests a bottom may be forming. Elsewhere on the AI front, I am expecting the adoption trend to continue going upwards to the right because of the new products launched. Over the past 12 months, CLVT rolled out 12 new AI-powered capabilities, and these are commercial-grade products that are valuable. Take the Derwent Patent Monitor, for example. It uses AI to assign threat ratings in IP portfolios. Essentially, it acts as a smart early-warning system that flags competitor filings that could be a risk to the organization. In the past, this was done through manually looking through thousands of new patents, which is extremely time-consuming and costly. But all this can now be done automatically, which not only cuts down labor costs but also de-risks an organization's business (that relies on their IP). Another good example is the Cortellis Regulatory Assistant, which uses conversational AI to make life easier when navigating a regulatory landscape. This is specifically useful for biopharma and medtech companies, where the regulatory landscape is complex and profound. Instead of looking through each legal note, this AI tool allows an organization to ask questions (like how you ask ChatGPT something) and receive answers in seconds. Again, over here, there will be a lot of time and cost saved.

The Bear Case

Now for the bear case, which is a strong one that frankly has pushed me back from bullish to neutral in the near term. The most disappointing development was that the turnaround narrative is somewhat broken. My earlier view on this recovery was based on the steady organic growth acceleration (0.3% in Q1 2025, followed by 0.5% in Q2, which I expected to continue). But this quarter, that trend turned for the worse. Total organic revenue fell -0.1% y/y, and as much as there are positive signals, this was a really huge setback that kills that recovery narrative (at least for the near-term).

The bigger problem is that this organic decline was in the two segments that needed to turn around the most. Intellectual property remains the biggest drag, with organic revenue down 2.7% y/y, including a 3.2% decline in recurring patent renewals. This is very bad because it is exactly the part of the business that needs to stabilize first, yet it’s still shrinking. Think about it, the recurring patent renewals are the “base” of the business that gives recurring revenue, which CLVT can use to reinvest for growth. If that continues to shrink, the business will just be too tough to be in growth mode. The LSH segment also saw a 0.7% organic decline. While ANG is growing, it doesn’t matter because the other two segments represent the majority of adj. EBITDA, so until they recover, the earnings outlook is just not great.

Valuation

All of this circles back to valuation and, more importantly, trust. I’d been vocal that the stock looked cheap, but I think it is also fair that the market remains skeptical, and Q3 proved the market right. The headline beat was not structural, and the underlying organic growth trend has turned for the worse. This certainly does not help when CLVT has a record of missing consensus estimates.

So, despite the stock becoming cheaper than when I wrote about it last time (now at 4.8x forward PE), I am revising my rating to hold. Until management can deliver clean, consistent core organic growth, it doesn’t matter if the ACV growth trend is positive. I don’t think that alone will move the stock. In my view, the shares will stay in this penalty box for now.

Conclusion

I downgrade to a hold rating for CLVT. The bull case that I thought would happen failed to materialize, with the organic growth trend turning negative. While there are bright spots like a growing subscription mix, early traction from AI products, and solid retention, there is just no strong momentum in the broader turnaround. Until CLVT delivers durable organic growth, I expect the stock to remain range-bound.

data.title: Monolithic Power Systems - Structural Strength Meets Valuation Risk
data.description:
Monolithic Power Systems Inc.’s (MPWR) share price has been trending upward over the past six months. This is likely reflecting investor optimism following the company’s performance in the last few quarters.

The Q3 2025 results continued to demonstrate MPS’s structural growth strength, with revenue up 18.9% year-on-year and stable margins.

I would argue that these results are not merely cyclical or temporary. Rather, they stem from the structural strengths that underpin Monolithic Power Systems Inc.’s (MPS) long-term growth story.

In this article, I examine the company’s performance over the past decade to uncover the underlying drivers behind its exceptional compounding record — focusing on the strategic, operational, and structural factors that continue to sustain its growth and profitability.

Investment Thesis

MPS is a high-quality analog semiconductor firm with structural, organic growth driven by proprietary power-management IP, deep customer integration, and an efficient fabless model. Its exposure to data center, automotive, and industrial markets supports continued double-digit earnings growth. While financially sound with peer-leading performance, much of its strength is already priced in.

Organic-driven growth

MPS is a fabless analog semiconductor company generating almost all its revenue from sales of proprietary power-management ICs and modules. Its value proposition combines advanced analog design, high integration, and energy efficiency, underpinned by a strong balance sheet and asset-light manufacturing model.

Over the past decade, the company managed to grow revenue at a 23% CAGR. Management explicitly credited its engineering-driven growth model - rather than M&A or one-off demand surges - as the source of its long-term outperformance.

This growth was almost entirely organic, fueled by consistent innovation, deeper customer integration, and expansion into larger, higher-value markets.

MPS serves the global power management IC market, a moderately growing one as exemplified by the following:

“The global power management IC market size was estimated at USD 40,293.8 million in 2024…growing at a CAGR of 6.8% from 2025 to 2030.” Grand View Research

“The global power management IC market size was valued at USD 39.39 billion in 2024…exhibiting a CAGR of 6.5% during the forecast period (2024 to 2032)." Fortune Business Insights

While the time horizons differ, it nonetheless illustrates that MPS’s historical revenue growth has significantly outpaced the broader market. This implied that its expansion was driven primarily by market-share gains rather than overall sector growth.

As I will show later in the peer analysis section, MPS achieved the best revenue growth rate among the peers, supporting this market share gain picture.

Moats

I believe that a big part of its growth was due to the following competitive advantages:

i) Intangibles. MPS has proprietary analog and mixed-signal power-management architectures, patented process technologies, and advanced packaging IP.

ii) Customer embeddedness - Deep engineering integration and long-term partnerships. Many programs are custom-tuned or co-developed. This integration raises the cost for customers to disengage and strengthens MPS’s insight into upcoming product roadmaps.

iii) Capital efficiency advantage - Fabless model. This setup allows MPS to maintain lower fixed-cost burdens, respond flexibly to demand, and reinvest more into R&D. These support long-term margin resilience and innovation cycles.

The above analysis suggests that the MPS growth trajectory is structural rather than cyclical, and it is likely to sustain its historical double-digit pace for some time. With China accounting for roughly half its revenue in recent years, MPS has leveraged its global presence to penetrate large, fast-evolving end markets.

Higher profit growth

MPS was able to leverage its high revenue growth into a much stronger profit growth. Over the past decade, operating profit and PAT grew at 34% and 55% respectively.

Chart 1 provides some insights into the profit drivers. You can see that the gross profit margin (and the corresponding contribution margin) did not change much over the past decade.

What was significant was fixed cost control. Over the past decade, fixed cost margin declined (improved) with the 2024 margin of 33% compared to the 46% in 2015.

The other characteristic of its cost structure was the high operating leverage, with fixed costs accounting for about half of the total cost (fixed + variable). This meant that additional revenue will have a multiplier impact on profits.

In Q3 2025, operating profit rose 19% year-on-year on an 18.9% revenue increase, confirming that operating leverage remains strong even as gross margins plateau near 55%.

Taken together, the decade-long trend suggests an underlying efficient business model. Given the projected revenue growth discussed earlier, it is reasonable to expect that profit growth will remain strong and sustainable.

Note to Op Profit Model. I broke down the operating profits into fixed costs and variable costs.

  • Fixed cost = SG&A, R&D, Depreciation & Amortization.
  • Variable cost = Cost of Sales - Depreciation and Amortization.
  • Contribution = Revenue – Variable Cost.
  • Contribution margin = Contribution/Revenue.

The PAT growth rate was higher than that for the operating profit because of the $1.2 billion tax credit in 2024. This tax credit arose mainly from share-based compensation deductions and R&D-related tax incentives. The tax credit was not from one-off accounting reversals or deferred tax releases. Excluding the tax credit and assuming the “normal” tax rate, the PAT growth rate from 2015 to 2024 is about 34% CAGR.

Having said that, it is instructive to note that the effective tax rate over the past decade (excluding the tax credit year) was about 12%. This is much lower than the nominal tax rate because of its global footprint, tax-efficient operating structure, and recurring credits tied to R&D and stock-based compensation.

In other words, the lower tax rate can be considered part of the business setup and expected to be sustained.

Peer analysis

I compared MPS’s performance with the following publicly listed peers.

i) Analog Devices: This is a high-performance analog/mixed-signal giant supplying precision/power solutions into industrial, automotive, and data-center systems. It is a direct overlap in premium power-management and mixed-signal solutions for the same customers and systems.

ii) Infineon Technologies: This is a global power semiconductor leader with broad portfolios in automotive, industrial power, and power conversion. It competes with MPS in automotive and industrial power-management architectures and modules.

iii) ON Semiconductor: This is a power and sensing company focused on automotive/industrial energy-efficient solutions, including advanced power-conversion and SiC. It has an overlapping focus on high-efficiency power for EV, industrial automation, and data-center/communications.

iv) STMicroelectronics: This is an analog/mixed-signal and power-discrete supplier to automotive, industrial, and communications. It competes across multiple MPS categories in power management and shares key end markets.

v) Texas Instruments: This is a diversified analogue and embedded semiconductor leader with a deep catalogue of power-management ICs across industrial, automotive, and communications. It competes head-to-head in high-performance power management across the same end markets.

As shown in Table 1, MPS is the smallest in terms of the 2024 revenue but had the best revenue growth rate from 2015 to 2024.

Notes to Table 1:

a) Except for Analog (FYE Oct) and Infineon (FYE Sep), all the others had Dec as the financial year-end.

b) The years in the peer analysis were based on the financial years.

I compared MPS’s peer performance based on several metrics shown in Charts 2 to 4.

I would assess its overall performance as good to excellent relative to its peers:

i) Financial Strength – outstanding. MPS consistently maintained the lowest debt-to-capital ratio, signalling prudent balance sheet management and strong internal cash generation.

ii) Profitability and Efficiency – strong. MPS sustained top-tier return on capital, indicating efficient capital deployment and superior reinvestment discipline. Its EBIT margins were slightly below the top quartile, reflecting continued investment and a focus on growth rather than peak margins.

iii) Cash Flow Quality - very good. MPS ranked second on free cash flow margin with low variability, implying resilient earnings conversion and strong operating leverage.

iv) EPS Growth – excellent. It has the best EPS growth rate among peers, underscoring superior execution, product innovation, and expansion across key end markets.

Notes to Charts 2 to 4:

i) Compared to the peers, MPS generally had the lowest (best) debt-capital ratio over the review period.

ii) MPS started in the No.3 position in terms of the return on capital. But 2 years later, it ranked No.2 and stayed in this position till 2023. In 2024, it ranked the best. Overall, MPS ranked No. 2 in terms of the average return on capital over the review period.

iii) In terms of the EBIT margin, except for 2022 (No. 4) and 2023 (No. 5), MPS ranked No. 3 over the review period. Overall, MPS ranked No. 3 in terms of the average EBIT margin. Texas Instruments had the best overall average EBIT margin of 41%.

iv) Overall, MPS ranked No. 2 in terms of the average free cash flow margin over the review period. Its free cash flow margin was also among the least variable.

v) MPS had the best EPS growth rate from 2015 to 2024.

Financial position

I would rate MPS as financially sound as its positive points more than make up for my concern over its cash flow conversion ratio.

i) As of Sep 2025, it had $1.3 billion in cash and short-term investments, equivalent to 30% of its total assets.

ii) It is effectively debt-free at the end of Sep 2025.

iii) Over the past decade, it had an average Reinvestment rate (Reinvestment/NOPAT) of 39%. I defined Reinvestment = CAPEX & Acquisition – Depreciation & Amortization + increase in Net Working Capital.

iv) I would rate its capital allocation plan over the past decade as good. Refer to Table 2. This is because the cash flow from operations was enough to cover its acquisitions and CAPEX. Excess was returned to shareholders.

The main concern is its cash flow. From 2015 to 2024, while it generated an annual positive cash flow from operations every year, it did not have a good cash flow conversion ratio. During this period, it only generated $2.9 billion in cash flow from operations compared to its cumulative PAT of $3.4 billion.

Prospects

The outlook for MPS appears highly favorable, supported by growth drivers and sustained competitive advantages. Its historical performance has been driven by strong execution rather than cyclical tailwinds, and there is little evidence to suggest a reversal of this trajectory.

i) Market growth. Demand for power-management ICs in data centers, EVs, and industrial automation would provide long-term growth opportunities.

ii) Market share gains. Continuous innovation and customer integration should enable MPS to capture share from larger analog competitors.

iii) Margin resilience. I expect a continuation of its strong cost discipline and high operating leverage. This would support sustained profitability and scalable earnings growth.

iv) Geographic diversification. While China remains its largest market, expanding exposure in North America and Europe would gradually reducing concentration risk.

v) Earnings visibility. Its long-term customer programs, a debt-free balance sheet, and recurring tax benefits underpin high earnings and cash flow predictability.

In sum, MPS’s prospects remain strongly positive. The company’s moats - proprietary IP, customer embeddedness, and capital efficiency - are enduring and self-reinforcing.

While cyclical risks from the semiconductor demand environment cannot be ruled out, MPS’s business model is positioned to compound value structurally, not cyclically.

Recent results suggest that while structural growth continues, MPS’s revenue trajectory has normalized to the high-teens range, reflecting broad-based demand rather than outsized data center momentum.

Valuation

The value of MPS would depend on the profit trajectory. In this context, I assumed a picture tied to its historical performance. The key assumptions are as follows.

i) The base revenue would be the 2024 revenue. Over the valuation period (Year 1 to the terminal value in Year 6), revenue would grow at 23.2% CAGR. This is about the historical growth rate.

ii) The base EBIT margin would be based on the 2022 to 2024 average of 27%. I assumed that this would improve proportionately so that in the terminal year, it would match the peer's best historical average of 41%.

iii) The based capital turnover would be the 2022 to 2024 average value

iv) The base Reinvestment would be the past decade's average Reinvestment margin. The Reinvestment rate would improve proportionately so that in the terminal year, it would follow that of the fundamental growth equation.

v) The tax rate would be the past decade's average tax rate (excluding 2024).

On such a basis I obtained an intrinsic value of $725 per share compared to the market price of $1,094 per share (29 Oct 2025). There is no margin of safety

Valuation model

I value MPS based on a multi-stage valuation model as illustrated in Table 3.

Notes to Table 3.

a. Proportionate change

b. Pegged to growth rate

c. Assumed proportionate change

d. Based on past decade average restructuring, legal and non-op costs, growing at 4% pa

e. Revenue X Margin, and after accounting for Other costs

f. Assumed proportionate change

g. b X f

h. FCFF for each year = e - g

j. Refer to the WACC table

k. NPV for each year = (h X j)

l. Terminal for the year discounted at the terminal growth rate

m. 5 years NPV + terminal value

n. Inclusive of any excess TCE. Non-operating assets, MI, and Debt

o. Based on the number of diluted shares

The WACC was based on the Google Search for “Monolithic Power Systems WACC” as summarized in Table 4.

Risks and limitations

While you may think that my assumption of the historical revenue CAGR may not be aggressive, I would point out that the rest of the assumptions are aggressive ones. This is because in the terminal year:

i) MPS would deliver an EBIT margin of 44%. Its past decade high was only 29%. Given that margins appear to have stabilized (as per the Q3 2025 results) in the mid-30s operating range, my prior assumption of margin expansion toward peer highs may be very optimistic.

ii) MPS would have a 101% return on capital. The peer best over the past decade was by Texas Instruments with 47% in 2018.

iii) MPS would have an EPS of $57 per share. Its decade best was $9 per share.

Despite an aggressive set of assumptions, there is no margin of safety. The market has overpriced the business.

Conclusion

MPS represents a rare combination of sustained organic growth, structural efficiency, and durable competitive advantages in the analog semiconductor space.

Over the past decade, the company has compounded revenue at 23% annually, translating this into even stronger profit. This was achieved through disciplined cost control and operating leverage.

Its competitive edge rests on proprietary power-management architectures, deep customer integration, and an asset-light, fabless model that allows consistent reinvestment into innovation.

Looking ahead, MPS’s core markets remain structurally attractive. These - data centers, automotive, and industrial systems - are driven by rising power density, electrification, and AI-related demand. These tailwinds, combined with the company’s engineering-led culture and design-in model, support a strong likelihood of continued double-digit growth.

However, from an investment perspective, much of this strength already appears priced into the stock. Even when modelled with optimistic growth and margin assumptions, intrinsic value estimates offer little to no margin of safety relative to current market levels. You can understand why I do not see this as a long-term value investing opportunity.

data.title: The 1-Minute Market Report November 2, 2025
data.description:
The S&P 500 made two more new highs last week, on Monday and Tuesday. That makes 35 for the year so far. We had a strong finish for October after a strong showing in the traditionally weak month of September.

As is customary, I will look at the various asset classes, sectors, equity categories, exchange-traded funds (ETFs), and stocks that moved the market higher and the market segments that defied the trend by moving lower.

Identifying the pockets of strength and weakness allows us to see the direction of significant money flows and their origin. This is helpful in a trending market like we have today, as opposed to a choppy, directionless market. Once a trend gets going, it usually continues until something fundamentally changes the direction of the trend.

S&P 500 had a tepid week

As I said at the top, the market made two new high last week. With the government shutdown, a weakening employment picture, and still unresolved tariff negotiations, investors are assuming that the so-called ‘Fed put’ is still in play. But I beg to differ. With the budget deficit and national debt so high, the Fed will be reluctant to add any meaningful stimulus or do any rescuing of banks or brokers who get into trouble.

Zoom out to 12 months

This chart shows the monthly returns for the past year. October began in the red but rallied strongly to finish solidly in the green..

S&P 500 drawdowns

Here is a closer look at drawdowns. You can see the March-April slide, and the V-shaped recovery after. Ever since then we’ve been hugging the zero drawdown line, with the worst drawdown since April at about -3%.

A look at the bull run since it began in October 2022.

This chart highlights the 85.1% gain in the S&P 500 from the October 2022 low through Friday's close. We are comfortably above the long term trendline.

Confession time: I forgot to update the next series of charts after I posted this article last week. The result is that – for this week only – you will be looking at what happened in the market over the past 2 weeks instead of one week.

Major index performance last 2 weeks

All major indices were higher for the period. Nasdaq led the way.

Major asset class performance.

Here is a look at the performance of some major asset classes, sorted by the last 2 weeks' returns. The way you allocate your capital across asset classes accounts for as much as 90% of the variability of your portfolio returns.

Blockchain companies surged higher again. Could it be that cryptocurrencies are now considered to be a safe haven in volatile markets? Maybe, but I’m inclined to think not. We already have gold and bonds and cash to do that. Cryptocurrencies may be here to stay, but they sure are volatile.

Equity sector performance

Tech continues to lead the market higher. Consumer Staples got the short end of the stick. Energy stocks moved higher in what some pundits are calling a 2-week dead cat bounce.

Factor returns

All of the factors were up, with high beta names leading by a wide margin.

Growth vs. Value returns

Growth beat Value last week as investors showed confidence in the durability of this rally.

Commodities returns

Crude oil and gasoline led the way higher over the last 2 weeks, while gold and silver shed some of their gains.

Non-U.S. market returns

Brazil was the clear favorite over the last 2 weeks, while France and Germany succumbed to profit taking.

Equity group performance

For the groups, I separate the stocks in the S&P 1500 Composite Index by shared characteristics like growth, value, size, cyclical, defensive, and domestic vs. foreign.

For the past 2 weeks the Mag 7 have led the market higher. Defensive stocks like Consumer Staples and Utilities lost ground.

The S&P Mag 7

Here is a look at the seven mega-cap stocks that have been leading the market over the past few years. These seven stocks account for 39% of the total YTD gain in the S&P 500.

On a 2 week basis, META was clearly in last place with a decline of 12.2%. Amazon beat their numbers on Friday, which kicked the stock into high gear.

The S&P Top 7 Share of Gains.

The ten best-performing ETFs Year-to-Date

No surprise that gold miners is the leading ETF, up 112.4% YTD. Nuclear Energy is second, with a gain of 79.1%.

The ten worst-performing ETFs Year-to-Date

You can ignore the YTD number for Bitcoin. In reality, it’s up 12.3%, not down 20.6%. I take full responsibility for the mixup.

BDC Income is having a tough year, as is Natural Gas.

The ten best-performing momentum stocks Year-to-Date

Here are the 10 best performing stocks in the S&P 1500 on a year-to-date basis. Hats off to Viasat (VSAT) for coming in at number one. MP Materials (MP) had been leading the pack for most of the year until news leaked out about a deal with China, where we can still access their rare earth metals. Wolfspeed (WOLF) is benefiting from meme stock momentum.

Final thoughts

What started out with a bang, and two new highs on Monday and Tuesday, ended up with a fizzle for the rest of the week, for a net gain of 0.7%. A gain is a gain, as they say, but recently the market has been doing better than 0.7%. My message to Mr. Market is… Try harder! We don’t want to meander higher. We want to rocket higher, valuations be damned.

Speaking of valuations, we’re getting up there. We’re close to 1999 caliber valuations. Can we surpass that ceiling? Of course we can. But be aware that there is a price to pay for buying richly valued stocks. The returns going forward hardly ever reach the highs that are achieved when starting valuations are more reasonable. It just makes intuitive sense.

To recap the last 2 week’s action, investors were:

  • Selling foreign markets and buying NASDAQ stocks
  • Selling REITs and buying blockchain companies
  • Selling Consumer Staples and buying Tech
  • Selling dividend yield and buying high-beta stocks
  • Selling Value and buying Growth
  • Selling Gold & Silver and buying Crude oil
  • Selling France and buying Brazil
  • Selling uranium and buying lithium
  • Selling Defensive and buying Cyclical stocks
